awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Topology: Methods, Computation, and Science 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Topology: Methods, Computation, and Science (ATMCS) is a biennial conference on algebraic topology and its applications. The tenth ATMCS meeting will be hosted by Oxford University, the week of June 20–24, 2022. The program includes invited talks, contributed talks, and a poster session. As many as 350 participants from around the world are expected at the conference. This project will support the travel of US-based participants to the meeting. 

The areas represented at the meeting will include multivariate persistent homology, directed topology, stochastic topology, inverse problems, algorithms and software development, topological data analysis (TDA) in machine learning, network data analysis, and applications of TDA. By supporting the cross pollination of ideas, the conference will directly impact research in the United States. Participant support costs will be prioritized for early-career researchers. A conference website is available at https://atmcs.web.ox.ac.uk/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the travel of early-career US participants in the conference Algebraic Topology: Methods, Computation, and Science (ATMCS), which was hosted in Oxford in June 2022. This is the main conference in applied algebraic topology and topological data analysis, normally held every other year. Due to the pandemic, it was the first chance for many early-career participants to attend a conference of this kind. Several of the supported participants displayed posters or gave contributed talks.
Due to ongoing effects of the pandemic as well as visa issues, there were travel funds remaining in the award after ATMCS 2022. The award also supported travel by early-career particpants to an IMSI workshop on "Randomness in Topology and its Applications" in Chicago, and a special session in topological data analysis at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in San Francisco. These meetings also gave participants opportunities to hear about the last research in applied algebraic topology, to meet with senior researchers in the area, and to present their own work.

These meetings all contributed to the intellectual development of the rapidly developing field of applied algebraic topology. Being able to attend conferences and workshops like this is a crucial part of the training and professional developments of early-career researchers. 


Last Modified: 09/18/2024
Modified by: Matthew K Kahle
